19th_century.label: 19th-Century Fashion Theory
19th_century.short: Fashion shaped by industrialization, class distinction, and early consumer culture.
19th_century.extended: 19th-century fashion theory is discussed through industrial modernity, class signaling, and the emergence of mass production and bourgeois taste.
19th_century.research: Consult university fashion history programs, museum costume institutes, and peer-reviewed historical studies.

early_20th_century.label: Early 20th-Century Fashion Theory
early_20th_century.short: Fashion influenced by modernism, social reform, and changing gender roles.
early_20th_century.extended: Early 20th-century discussions focus on modernism, functionalism, and shifting norms of dress in relation to social change.
early_20th_century.research: Refer to institutional archives, design history departments, and modernist studies in academic literature.

late_20th_century.label: Late 20th-Century Fashion Theory
late_20th_century.short: Postmodernism, identity politics, and global fashion systems.
late_20th_century.extended: Late 20th-century fashion theory engages with postmodernism, semiotics, subcultures, and globalization.
late_20th_century.research: Use cultural studies journals, university libraries, and museum research portals for peer-reviewed analysis.
